messages: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:43): 2466054b396284f05e6f6e4e7d3c806d: the extension might poke at stuff in a cross-compartment way or something
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:46): did sicking volunteer to write a fourth CP for ISSUE-27?
2466054b396284f05e6f6e4e7d3c806d (14:47): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: No, it's not the extension
2466054b396284f05e6f6e4e7d3c806d (14:47): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: disabled both ones that got updated.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:48): othermaciej: according to the minutes, sicking volunteered to write a fourth CP for ISSUE-27
2466054b396284f05e6f6e4e7d3c806d (14:48): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: So far only managed to trace it, sort of, to www.speedtree.com and www.facefx.com being open at the same time
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:49): 2466054b396284f05e6f6e4e7d3c806d: I wonder if they share the ad provider or something of that nature
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:50): what change proposal would sicking write?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:50): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: delegating rel registry to microformats.org

2466054b396284f05e6f6e4e7d3c806d (14:51): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Only symptom I noticed is that those open with the ones I already have open causes my dual core to show 20%-40% CPU utilization even if the tab is not focused on either of those two sites.
2466054b396284f05e6f6e4e7d3c806d (14:51): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: The memory leaks apparently needs 4-5 extra pages open, which I had closed trying to nail this issue. :S
2466054b396284f05e6f6e4e7d3c806d (14:51): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I seriously dislike trying to come up with a repro case like this :(
2466054b396284f05e6f6e4e7d3c806d (14:52): bloody heisenbugs
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:53): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, yeah, that is said in the minutes
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:54): with "new information" being experience with IANA
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:54): should we raise this on list?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:55): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: probably worthwhile to mention on the list
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:55): i will

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:56): aside, I find it questionable that when I file a crash bug using the Ubuntu crash reporting tool, the command line I used that contains potentially private file names is posted to launchpad publicly
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:56): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: thanks
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:56): now everyone can tell the names of the patches I'm working on
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:56): though I'm disclosing that information usually anyway for non-security bugs
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (15:00): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: just a quick note that I think I got it now - but I don't see why not supporting percent would be a bug then...
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:02): 040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721, UAs are required to process invalid content in the same way
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:02): 040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721, otherwise sites start using width="50%" and expect it to be treated as width="50" for instance
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (15:02): so we distinguish between different kinds of invalid?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:03): no
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (15:03): well, 50% is different invalid from 50px
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:03): we distinguish between authors and user agents
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:03): it's not different invalid
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:03): it has different behavior
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (15:04): so‚Ä¶ it's invalid from a standard POV, but it's kinda valid for an author, because browsers show a defined behaviour?
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (15:05): (where "it" are both those examples ;-)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:08): you are trying to draw lines that are not really there
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:09): it is as invalid as e.g. <style>body{background:green</style>
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (15:09): I'm trying to consolidate in my own mind how "invalid" and "defined behaviour" gel
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:10): well, the way we write specifications they are mostly orthogonal
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:10): in the sense that everything "works" and a subset of that is "valid"
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:10): (the subset that makes sense, ideally)
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (15:11): So - it's not just because sometimes markup is incomplete, it's also because people have expectations from things that used to work?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:13): 040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721: what authors need to know is what is valid
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:14): 040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721: no need to say what browsers will do when they break the rules
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (15:15): well, for things that get typically done wrong, it makes sense to mention it IMHO
